section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards for letter review: goat, gift, duck, dog, umbrella, up; Alphabet Cards for activity: cat, duck, dog, fish, fox, goat, gift, hat, nut, nest, sun, vest, jam, ring, sock.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Anywhere Farm. We practiced blending sounds to make a word.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Gg, Dd, Uu Alphabet Cards Show the uppercase and lowercase letters for all of the target sounds. Say a word and invite children to locate the picture that matches the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Now we are going to play a listening game. I am going to put together a beginning sound (the onset) and the rest of the word (the rime). I will use the sounds to blend a word. Then you will find the picture that shows the word I blended.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Display five of the Alphabet Card pictures at a time. Begin with duck, dog, nut, sun, and goat. Say the sounds for the first onset and rhyme, d + og. Invite a child to locate the correct picture. After it is correctly selected, turn over the card.
Repeat Continue with d + uck; n + ut; s + un; and g + oat.

Extend Use another set of five cards and continue the activity. After all the cards have been used, invite children to turn over a card, model the onset and rime, and have children repeat it after you.
Writing Letters Gg, Dd, Uu Children may enjoy tracing over dotted letters, writing letters in the air, or making letters in a sand or salt tray.

For some children, it might be better to limit the choice to two cards. Show two cards and say, Let’s blend the sounds. Which picture shows the word we blended? Have the word identified and say, Yes, the word we blended is and this picture shows a .

Challenge children to create their own pictures for words you present as onsets and rimes. Say each word as an onset and rime and then have children draw a quick picture to illustrate the word. Begin with these words: dog, bug, and nut. Children may also write the words.

Note that in Spanish, the letter Gg actually has three sounds: in addition to the hard and soft pronunciations as in English, the Spanish Gg can have an /h/ sound. Explain that in English, the Gg has two sounds, but in this lesson we are focusing the /g/ sound that g makes.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth for the onset sound and rime part. Children may need to hear the onset and rime several times before being able to identify the word.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65566-7. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need brown paper bags, each containing a real or play food vegetable. Use the Activity Cards from 7.3.3.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Anywhere Farm. We had fun asking each other questions and answering them.
When we ask and answer questions, we learn. Asking and answering questions is a way to find out about what we don’t know.

Today we will look at some pictures of vegetables. Then I will show you a bag with a hidden vegetable. You will ask lots of questions to find out what vegetable is hidden there. The answers to your questions will give you more and more information. Then you will be able to figure out what vegetable is hidden in the bag!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture at a time. Ask the questions on the back of the card.
Repeat Continue until you have looked at all the cards. Keep the cards displayed as you do the guessing activity.

Do the Activity Show a bag with a hidden vegetable. Invite children to take turns asking questions about what’s in the bag. If children need help, model the questioning: Is it big? Is it red? Is it juicy? Is it good for a salad? Do people mash it? Do people cook it? Does it have seeds in it?
Repeat Continue until all the vegetables have been guessed.
Talk About Asking and Answering Questions Guide children to discuss why it is so important for children to ask lots of questions.

For younger children, you may want to limit the activity. Show three Activity Cards and then have children guess what is in the bag. Continue with the next three Activity Cards and one more hidden vegetable to guess. Then do the last three.
To challenge children, place other food items in the bags and continue the question-asking activity.

As you do the Activity Cards, concentrate on each vegetable name and have children repeat the name after you introduce it. When you do the guessing activity, pair multilingual learners with English speakers so they can get help in forming questions and guesses.

Some children may benefit from sensory support. For those children, use real vegetables so that the children can touch each vegetable when it is introduced on the Activity Cards. Encourage children to touch and name each vegetable.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65566-7. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards, play money

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In the story, the girl takes a place at a farmers’ market where she sells the vegetables she has grown.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Activity Cards Use the Activity Cards to review the names of vegetables that will be for sale at today’s farmers’ market.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we will have a farmers’ market where you can decide what vegetables to buy. You will take turns being the buyer and the seller.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the Activity Cards face up and spread them out on the table so all are visible. Place the money on the table.

Ask Hand one child some money so she can be the buyer. Select another child to be the seller. Ask the buyer to name which vegetable she would like to buy. The seller picks up the card that shows the vegetable named. The buyer then hands the money to the seller in exchange for the vegetable she is purchasing. Encourage conversation between the buyer and seller.
Repeat Continue until everyone has an opportunity to be both the buyer and the seller.

Talk About Buying and Selling Note that in this activity, sometimes children were sellers and sometimes they were buyers. Invite children to share a time when they were with family members and were buyers. Ask them to talk about how their family member paid for something they wanted to buy.

Children are not responsible for knowing the names of all the vegetables. If children have difficulty naming the vegetable they want to buy, just invite them to say, “I’d like to buy this one,” as they point to the one they have chosen.
Encourage children to use play money and play fruits and vegetables to set up a farmers’ market and continue the activity in the Pretend and Learn Center.

Children who speak Spanish as a first language may find some words for vegetables are very similar in English and Spanish. Help them connect the words when possible to help them learn the English word. For example, broccoli = brócoli; squash = squash; lettuce = lechuga; potato = patata; tomato = tomate.

When other children are playing the roles of buyer and seller, some may have a difficult time waiting for their turn. Provide each child with a pretend food to hold while they are waiting their turn so they feel engaged in the activity.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65566-7. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Several pieces of play food; a paper towel; a closed box; and a basket.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In the story, Jack climbs up, up, up a very tall beanstalk. Then he climbs down, down, down the beanstalk.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Use the Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words beanstalk and climbed.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we will do an activity where you can show how to use different words that show where something is by comparing it to where something else is.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the play food, the paper towel, the box, and the basket on the table.
Ask Ask one child to select one piece of food and place it in the basket. Ask another child to describe where the fruit is located (for example, “The carrot is in the basket.”).

Repeat Continue with the other children and different prepositions so they have an opportunity to understand and use a variety of relational words (up, down, over, under, in, out, between, behind, next to, and near).

Practice Using Prepositions Throughout the day, use a variety of prepositions with children as they do their classroom activities, encouraging them both to understand and to use an increasing variety.

Model the relational location of the food item first and ask children to repeat after you. Continue to use the same preposition with different items until children have mastered the word before moving onto another preposition.
To challenge children, do the activity in reverse. Say a sentence that describes the location of an item using one of the prepositions. Invite children to listen and place the item where it belongs.

Model the meaning of a preposition by using the items and describing the location. Then, ask children to say the preposition and model the action. For example, place a potato in the basket and say: In. The potato is in the basket. Say it with me: in.

Assist children by beginning with yes or no questions about the relational location of the food, then encourage the children to model sentences after you, such as, Is the bean next to the pepper? (yes). Say this after me: ‘The bean is next to the pepper.’ (child repeats).

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65566-7. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
